questions.text: Most commonly implicated drug for idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Amoxicillin-clavulanate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury (DILI) occurs unpredictably and is unrelated to drug dose or duration. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is one of the most common causes of idiosyncratic DILI globally, often manifesting as a cholestatic or mixed pattern of liver injury. It is distinct from dose-dependent liver injury, such as that caused by paracetamol.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Valproate: Valproate-induced liver injury is typically idiosyncratic but less frequent than amoxicillin-clavulanate. Risk factors include young age and polytherapy with other antiepileptic drugs.
  • • Option B. Valproate:
  • • Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin rarely causes hepatotoxicity and is not a common cause of DILI. Its primary concerns relate to bleeding due to its anticoagulant effects.
  • • Option C. Warfarin:
  • • Option D. Paracetamol: Paracetamol is the leading cause of dose-dependent acute liver failure, not idiosyncratic DILI. Its toxicity is related to overdose or risk factors such as pre-existing liver disease.
  • • Option D. Paracetamol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a leading cause of idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury, presenting unpredictably and often unrelated to dose or duration. This is distinct from dose-dependent hepatotoxicity like that caused by paracetamol.

questions.text: Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs, whereas diazepam is a basic drug. Which of the following statement/s about these drugs is/are true? (Twisted PYQ) Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach and thus poorly absorbed. Diazepam is absorbed from the stomach due to its high lipid solubility. Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area. Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine, although to a lesser extent than the small intestine. Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs, like diarrhea, will decrease drug absorption in the small intestine.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 3, 4 and 5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The absorption of drugs depends on the non-ionized, lipid-soluble form of the drug, which crosses membranes more efficiently.
  • • Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area (True) : Like most drugs, phenobarbitone absorption is maximized in the small intestine, where the surface area for absorption is far greater than in the stomach. Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine (True) : Although the surface area of the large intestine is smaller than that of the small intestine, it can still absorb drugs. This is particularly relevant for sustained-release formulations or drugs undergoing enterohepatic recycling. Diseases decreasing transit time (True) : Conditions like diarrhea reduce the time available for drug absorption in the intestine, leading to reduced absorption.
  • • Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area (True) : Like most drugs, phenobarbitone absorption is maximized in the small intestine, where the surface area for absorption is far greater than in the stomach.
  • • Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area (True)
  • • Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine (True) : Although the surface area of the large intestine is smaller than that of the small intestine, it can still absorb drugs. This is particularly relevant for sustained-release formulations or drugs undergoing enterohepatic recycling.
  • • Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine (True)
  • • Diseases decreasing transit time (True) : Conditions like diarrhea reduce the time available for drug absorption in the intestine, leading to reduced absorption.
  • • Diseases decreasing transit time (True)
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach (False) : Aspirin, an acidic drug, remains largely non-ionized in the stomach and is capable of being absorbed there. However, its absorption is limited due to the short gastric emptying time. Diazepam is absorbed in the stomach (False) : Diazepam, a basic drug, becomes non-ionized in the alkaline pH of the intestine, where its lipid solubility facilitates maximal absorption.
  • • Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach (False) : Aspirin, an acidic drug, remains largely non-ionized in the stomach and is capable of being absorbed there. However, its absorption is limited due to the short gastric emptying time.
  • • Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach (False)
  • • Diazepam is absorbed in the stomach (False) : Diazepam, a basic drug, becomes non-ionized in the alkaline pH of the intestine, where its lipid solubility facilitates maximal absorption.
  • • Diazepam is absorbed in the stomach (False)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug absorption depends on the physicochemical properties of the drug (acidic or basic), the pH of the gastrointestinal tract, and the surface area available. Most absorption occurs in the small intestine due to its large surface area, irrespective of the drug's acidic or basic nature. Transit time significantly impacts absorption, with shorter times, such as in diarrhea, reducing drug absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-blockers is contraindicated in patients with congestive heart failure due to its intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pindolol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pindolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). Beta-blockers with ISA are generally contraindicated in heart failure as they can stimulate beta receptors, counteracting the benefits of beta blockade. This can increase myocardial workload and exacerbate heart failure, making pindolol unsuitable for these patients.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker but lacks ISA. While it is not preferred in heart failure management, it is not contraindicated like pindolol.
  • • Option A. Propranolol:
  • • Option B. Bisoprolol: Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker approved for use in heart failure. It decreases mortality by reducing sympathetic activation and improving heart function.
  • • Option B. Bisoprolol:
  • • Option D. Carvedilol: Carvedilol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking effects. It is highly effective in CHF management and has been proven to reduce mortality.
  • • Option D. Carvedilol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, such as pindolol, are contraindicated in heart failure due to their ability to increase myocardial workload. Preferred beta-blockers for CHF management include bisoprolol, carvedilol, and metoprolol, which reduce mortality by improving cardiac function and limiting sympathetic overdrive.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via a mechanism that involves inhibition of neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by targeting synaptobrevin? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tetanus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by cleaving synaptobrevin, a SNARE protein required for the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine in the central nervous system. This inhibition leads to unchecked excitatory signals, resulting in spastic paralysis, characterized by rigidity and muscle spasms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Botulinum: Botulinum toxin targets peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals, inhibiting the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This causes flaccid paralysis, not spastic paralysis.
  • • Option A. Botulinum:
  • • Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), leading to cell death, but does not affect neurotransmitter release.
  • • Option C. Diphtheria:
  • • Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin alters G-protein signaling by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, impacting cellular communication but not directly inhibiting neurotransmitter release.
  • • Option D. Pertussis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanus toxin causes spastic paralysis by cleaving synaptobrevin, disrupting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. This mechanism contrasts with botulinum toxin, which induces flaccid paralysis by targeting acetylcholine release in peripheral nerve endings.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization's classification, which categories of topical corticosteroids are considered "High Potency"?
questions.correct_answer: B. Class II and Class III
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Class II and Class III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The World Health Organization (WHO) has a system for classifying topical corticosteroids based on their potency, which ranges from Class I to Class VII. In this system, Class I is the most potent, and Class VII is the least potent. The classes are divided into groups according to their potency levels. The High Potency group specifically includes Class II and Class III corticosteroids. These classes are distinguished by their molecular activity, concentration, and the nature of their formulation vehicle, making them suitable for more severe dermatological conditions requiring stronger steroid action.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Class I and Class II : Incorrect because Class I is categorized under the Ultra-high-potency group, not the High-potency group.
  • • Option A. Class I and Class II
  • • Option C. Class III and Class IV : Incorrect as Class IV falls under the Moderate-potency group rather than the High-potency group.
  • • Option C. Class III and Class IV
  • • Option D. Class IV and Class V : Incorrect because both these classes are in the Moderate-potency group, which is lower than the High-potency classification.
  • • Option D. Class IV and Class V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class II and Class III topical corticosteroids are classified as "High Potency" according to the WHO classification system.

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is febrile and has moderate dehydration. What should be the treatment?(Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin and ORS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In febrile patients with diarrhea, the suspicion of a bacterial etiology such as invasive enteric pathogens (e.g., Salmonella, Shigella, or Campylobacter) increases. Empirical antibiotic therapy with ciprofloxacin is indicated in this case to address the bacterial infection. ORS is essential for rehydration to replace fluid and electrolyte losses due to moderate dehydration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Only ORS: ORS alone is insufficient in this case because the patient has fever and signs suggesting a bacterial cause, necessitating antibiotic treatment.
  • • Option B. Only ORS:
  • • Option C. Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole: While ciprofloxacin is appropriate, tinidazole is unnecessary unless a protozoal infection like amoebiasis or giardiasis is suspected, which is not indicated here.
  • • Option C. Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole:
  • • Option D. Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole, and ORS: Adding tinidazole without clear evidence of protozoal infection would be inappropriate and could lead to unnecessary side effects or resistance. Ciprofloxacin with ORS is adequate.
  • • Option D. Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole, and ORS:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with acute diarrhea and fever, empirical antibiotic therapy (e.g., ciprofloxacin) is indicated along with ORS for rehydration. Antibiotics should be avoided in afebrile patients with mild dehydration, where ORS alone suffices.

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher

options.label: C
options.text: Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

options.label: D
options.text: Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.correct_answer: C. Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.
  • ➤ As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.
  • ➤ The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female victim of RTA presents to the ER. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen is soft. The probable diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tension Pneumothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately causes collapse of the affected lung.
  • ➤ It is characterized by:
  • ➤ It is characterized by:
  • ➤ Chest pain Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness) Neck vein distention Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury Decreased chest movements on the affected side Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side
  • ➤ Chest pain
  • ➤ Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • ➤ Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • ➤ Neck vein distention
  • ➤ Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury
  • ➤ Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • ➤ Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • ➤ Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side
  • ➤ Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment must never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. Management includes:

In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line. Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

questions.text: A pregnant female in first trimester developed deep vein thrombosis. She requires anticoagulation. Which of the following will be the preferred drug in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Enoxaparin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because they do not cross the placenta and thus have a lower risk of fetal harm. Enoxaparin is effective in the treatment and prevention of DVT and is considered safe for use in pregnancy.

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity

options.label: B
options.text: Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs

options.label: C
options.text: Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.correct_answer: C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.
